data.title: Patrons' Reference Directory in Lee County, Illinois
data.meta_description: Free family records for researching ancestry in Illinois
data.text:
Transcription of Patrons' Reference Directory of Lee County, Illinois; tr. by GT-Team - MAW

[NOTE: This was a bit difficult to read, so the reearcher is advised to check it out for themselves]

Patrons' Reference Directory of Lee County, Illinois in 1900

Explanation. The date following a name indicates the length of time the party has been a resident of the county. The abbreviations are as follows: S. for Section; T. for Township; R. for Range; and P.O. for Post-office address. When no Section Number nor Township is given, it will be understood that the party resides within the limits of the village or city named, and, in such cases, the post-office address is the same as the place of residence, unless otherwise stated.

Badger, Chester, Retired, Binghampton village, P.O. Amboy. (Born in Colesville, Broome Co., NY, May 27, 1824. Parents, Chester S. and Lois (Bird) Badger, former a native of Massachusetts and the latter of Pennsylvania. Served as office boy with his uncle, Luther Badger, from age of 12 to age of 17 years. Then came to Illinois, driving overland in light spring wagon, reaching Lee Co., in 1840, where his parents had settled two years previous, on the old homestead, now the residence of Duer C. Badger. Served in Mexican war from 1846 to 1849. Drove overland to California. Returning two years later, engaged in manufacture of plows at Binghampton, and later in milling business. Converted old water-milll to steam mill, which was destroyed by fire in 1872. Married in 1854 Mary A. Cushman. Three children - Duer Chester, Cornelia E. and Robert. Prominent business man, and served as supervisor 7 years; on board of elections 13 years; school director and trustee many years, and still holds latter position. Known and esteemed throughout Lee and surrounding counties.
